image.altText: An Aboriginal man wearing a cap and stripey shirt.

items.synopsis: The gas industry's promise of fracking-related jobs in the Beetaloo Basin leaves some Aboriginal Territorians feeling hopeful and others suspicious.

title.children: Promise of fracking jobs divides Aboriginal people in 'forgotten' NT town

image.altText: RBA building

items.synopsis: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) warns further interest rate increases are still possible, as a former RBA governor says the low-rate era is over, leaving households feeling like Australia is heading for recession.

title.children: House price rebound appears to have clinched RBA rate rise in May, minutes reveal

image.altText: Deaclan Crowley standing outside Foodbank.

items.synopsis: Many Australians rely on cheaper food to get by, and new data shows an increase in people are accessing help from food charities for the first time.

title.children: Deaclan is seeking food relief for the first time in his life. He's part of a growing group of Australians

image.altText: Katy, a middle-aged woman in a salmon-pink top, sits at a table looking serious

items.synopsis: Home owner Katy says she's been struggling to meet her loan demands, and fears losing her home. What are the steps between missing a payment and losing your property?

title.children: Australians sell investment properties, refinance mortgages 'at a rate never before seen'

image.altText: A fire truck outside a building that is burnt on the top.

items.synopsis: A fire at Wellington's Loafers Lodge hostel is being treated as suspicious by authorities as people remain unaccounted-for.

title.children: Deadly New Zealand hostel blaze being treated as suspicious

image.altText: Three firefighters stand outside in the dark in Wellington with one being sprayed with sprinklers

items.synopsis: A hostel fire in New Zealand's capital has left multiple people dead in a "tragic event for all involved"  — as it happened.

title.children: Hostel resident tells of leaping from fourth floor window to escape deadly Wellington blaze — as it happened

image.altText: Julia Gillard sitting at a meeting table in a city office and speaking.

items.synopsis: Former prime minister Julia Gillard concedes that her desire to have a debate around the merit of marriage in modern society, instead of supporting same-sex marriage itself, was "wrong".

title.children: Gillard says she 'got it incredibly wrong' on same-sex marriage debate

image.altText: A graphic showing a corporate headshot of Richard Boyle with redacted cuttings from company documents behind him.

items.synopsis: It's a crisis that calls into question the wisdom of government outsourcing crucial functions and highlights the often cosy relationship between government, bureaucracy, regulators and the corporate world, writes Ian Verrender.

title.children: Richard Boyle faces life behind bars while those in the PwC scandal are protected by the corporate world

image.altText: The 'big four'

items.synopsis: Australia's under-pressure banks unveil a new tool to combat scam transactions, but consumer groups say they're still not doing enough to deal with an escalating problem.

title.children: Banks launch new weapon to help recover scam victims' money

image.altText: Samuel Lenarongoito stands with his family against a sunny backdrop at the Tennant Tur Club.

items.synopsis: Station workers, long term locals and Tennant Creek's international community embrace friends and fashion at the Two Cup Race Day.

title.children: In Tennant Creek a yearly horse race is bringing together new and long-term residents

image.altText: Victoria, who has shoulder-length blonde hair, looks calmly at the camera in a close-up portrait.

items.synopsis: On the day former police officer Brett Johnson is sentenced for abusing his position of power to pursue vulnerable women, one of his victims speaks exclusively to the ABC about the devastating impact his offending had on her life.

title.children: A police officer's misconduct shattered Victoria's life. He has today been jailed for six months

image.altText: A composite image of three women. One of the women holds a baby.

items.synopsis: Hopes, dreams, and disappointment. Five women aged between 24 and 41 share their stories of egg freezing.

title.children: Dreams and disappointments: Women share their stories of egg freezing

image.altText: Tight shot of Elon Musk, a white man with short brown hair and brown eyes, wearing a black suit & open-neck white shirt.

items.synopsis: The government of the US Virgin Islands has issued Tesla chief Elon Musk with a court order for documents in its lawsuit that is seeking to hold an American bank, JPMorgan Chase, liable for sex trafficking acts by Jeffrey Epstein.

title.children: US Virgin Islands issues Elon Musk with court order for documents in case against Jeffrey Epstein's bank

image.altText: Long animal livestock transport truck parked on the side of the road, sunset in the background.

items.synopsis: Truck drivers say smaller vehicles are the leading cause of crashes involving heavy haulage vehicles and that more education is needed.

title.children: Truckies call out 'ridiculous behaviour' of drivers in smaller vehicles amid claims accidents increasing

image.altText: A Red Rooster store and a Cold Rock store

items.synopsis: Two Victorian fast-food businesses are hit with hundreds of charges for allegedly failing to comply with child labour laws, as the state's watchdog cracks down on hospitality and retail franchises.

title.children: Two fast-food businesses hit with hundreds of charges for allegedly failing to comply with child labour laws

items.synopsis: Ningaloo's sparkling turquoise waters and marine life are well known to many, but this World Heritage treasure extends to the land, too — and conservationists fear its future is on a knife's edge.

title.children: A breathtaking journey into one of the last intact wild places on Earth

image.altText: A person in all white protective gear treating a big area of black mould on the wall of a house

items.synopsis: Rental properties are more likely be mouldy than other homes and excessive mould growth is known to harm human health. So what can you do about it?

title.children: We're heading in to 'mega mould' season and renters are at greater risk

image.altText: Two dinosaurs running through a small forrest on a spinning rock graphic.

items.synopsis: Palaeontologist Scott Hocknull likened his research to a crime scene, minus the criminals and eyewitnesses. Now, he's using technology to better understand the fossils found in Australia.

title.children: How experts are solving the mystery of Queensland's famous Lark Quarry dinosaur trackways

image.altText: A drago queen with a green and pick hat blowing confetti.

items.synopsis: Betty Confetti's Rainbow Story Time show is intended to promote diversity and inclusion, but it has been called off at a regional NSW library due to safety concerns.

title.children: Drag queen's library show for children cancelled after staff threatened

image.altText: Dr Janin Bredehoeft 1

items.synopsis: An embarrassing day is coming for Australian businesses that have a large gender pay gap, with the data from individual organisations to be made public.

title.children: 'Your gender pay gap is X, why would I go and work for you?': The revealing day coming for Australian businesses

image.altText: Man wearing a suit, standing next to a window.

items.synopsis: Following the release of the damning Brereton report in November 2020, Defence confirmed Army had "initiated administrative action against 17 individuals where there was an alleged failure to meet ADF expectations".

title.children: Defence insists due process was given to accused soldiers as anger grows over Afghanistan inquiry fallout

image.altText: a man standing outdoors on a paddock with cows behind him and wearing a cap and looking out over the land

items.synopsis: NSW farmer Alastair McLaren has lost hundreds of thousands of dollars due to contamination from PFAS chemicals, but he's not one of the 30,000 people who will be compensated.

title.children: Alastair lost his business due to pollution from toxic foam — but he won't get a cent from a class action payout

image.altText: Donald Trump in blue suit and red tie speaking at podium with US flag in the background.

items.synopsis: The FBI lacked evidence to investigate Donald Trump's 2016 presidential campaign and relied too heavily on tips provided by Mr Trump's political opponents to fuel the probe, US Special Counsel John Durham concluded in a report released on Monday.

title.children: FBI lacked evidence for alleged Trump-Russia collusion probe, US Special Counsel finds

image.altText: A logo above a petrol sign reading: "Exxon" in red letters.

items.synopsis: Indonesian villagers — who allege they were subjected to torture, sexual assault, beatings and watching their loved ones being shot by Indonesian soldiers contracted by ExxonMobil in 2001 — agree to a settlement. WARNING: This story contains details some readers may find distressing.

title.children: Exxon Mobil settles Indonesian torture case after more than 20 years

image.altText: A black and white image of a dam that has been blown apart.

items.synopsis: Today marks 80 years since the Dambusters Raid during World War II, a mission so secretive the crews didn't even know their target until the night before.

title.children: The WWII mission from 'hell' that saw pilots fly just above water at 370kph in enemy territory

image.altText: A woman

items.synopsis: Homicide detectives have revisited the investigation into the death of Healesville woman Marea Yann in 2003. A $1 million reward for information is being offered.

title.children: Marea was killed 'in the place she should have felt safest'. Decades later, police are offering a $1m reward

image.altText: A man stands in front of red and green indicator boards.

items.synopsis: Australian shares fall in afternoon trade, while the Reserve Bank warns there may be further interest rate hikes, and consumer confidence sinks to its lowest levels since the early days of the COVID-19 pandemic and the 1990s recession.

title.children: ASX slips, Reserve Bank warns of further rate hikes, consumer confidence sinks to COVID-19 lows

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australia's competition watchdog has confirmed it will look into natural gas retailers' market behaviour and expects them to pass through cheaper supplies to consumers. The government has ramped up scrutiny of the gas industry, introducing price caps and proposing to expand powers to curb liquefied natural gas (LNG) exports from east coast plants to ensure sufficient supply for domestic consumers at affordable prices. Gas producers, however, have said the measures would deter investment in new supply crucial for the east coast, home to most of the country's population and gas-dependent manufacturers. The objective of the government's intervention is to have enough supply for east coast markets at a reasonable price, Anna Brakey, commissioner of the Australian Competition & Consumer Commission (ACCC), told the APPEA industry conference. "We will now turn our focus to retailers," she said. Retailers are expected to pass on cheaper gas prices to consumers and if this does not happen, it will provide further recommendations to the government, Ms Brakey said. The country's top gas retailers are Origin Energy, AGL Energy and EnergyAustralia (owned by Hong Kong's CLP Holdings). "What we really want to see is a thriving market that can serve both the domestic and international market commitments," she said. "We are projecting a (gas supply) shortfall from 2027, (but) we do hope that new supply will come in to fill that gap." In a January report, the ACCC said forecast gas production is insufficient to meet forecast demand in the east coast from 2027.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ACCC to probe retailers' gas prices

children.content: Australia's competition watchdog has confirmed it will look into natural gas retailers' market behaviour and expects them to pass through cheaper supplies to consumers.
The government has ramped up scrutiny of the gas industry, introducing price caps
and proposing to expand powers to curb
liquefied natural gas (LNG)
exports from east coast plants to ensure sufficient supply for domestic consumers at affordable prices.
Gas producers, however, have said the measures would deter investment in new supply crucial for the east coast, home to most of the country's population and gas-dependent manufacturers.
The objective of the government's intervention is to have enough supply for east coast markets at a reasonable price,
Anna Brakey
, commissioner of the Australian Competition
Consumer Commission (ACCC), told the APPEA industry conference.
"We will now turn our focus to retailers," she said.
Retailers are expected to pass on cheaper gas prices to consumers and if this does not happen, it will provide further recommendations to the government, Ms Brakey said.
The country's top gas retailers are Origin Energy,
AGL Energy and EnergyAustralia (owned by Hong Kong's CLP Holdings).
"What we really want to see is a thriving market that can serve both the domestic and international market commitments," she said.
"We are projecting a (gas supply) shortfall from 2027, (but) we do hope that new supply will come in to fill that gap."
In a January report, the ACCC said forecast gas production is insufficient to meet forecast demand in the east coast from 2027.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: ANZ's economics team is expecting "one final rate hike" from the Reserve Bank in August, after reading the minutes of the bank's May board meeting. The final paragraph of the RBA minutes says: "Members also agreed that further increases in interest rates may still be required, but that this would depend on how the economy and inflation evolve." In that context, ANZ economist Adam Boyton wrote in a note to clients that "the use of the plural ... does (again) raise the prospect that rates may rise by more and/or earlier than we expect." "We see the risks around our expectation of one final 25 basis point rate hike in August being that the RBA hikes more and/or sooner than we anticipate. "Easing remains some considerable time off." Simply put, ANZ is not expecting rate cuts to happen for a while (basically suggesting the market's expectations are a little too optimistic).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ANZ tips one final RBA rate hike in August

children.content: ANZ's economics team is expecting "one final rate hike" from the Reserve Bank in August, after reading the minutes of the bank's May board meeting.
The final paragraph of the RBA minutes says: "Members also agreed that further
increases
in interest rates may still be required, but that this would depend on how the economy and inflation evolve."
In that context, ANZ economist Adam Boyton wrote in a note to clients that "the use of the plural ... does (again) raise the prospect that rates may rise by more and/or earlier than we expect."
"We see the risks around our expectation of one final 25 basis point rate hike in August being that the RBA hikes more and/or sooner than we anticipate.
"Easing remains some considerable time off."
Simply put, ANZ is not expecting rate
cuts
to happen for a while (basically suggesting the market's expectations are a little too optimistic).

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian dollar has slipped 0.3% to 66.8 US cents. The local currency fell after the latest economic data from key trading partner China fell short of analysts' forecasts, adding to evidence of a sputtering COVID recovery. China's industrial output grew 5.6% in April (from a year earlier), according to official data. This missed expectations by a large margin, as economists were expecting a 10.9% increase. But it was still the quicket growth since September 2022, largely due to the recoil effect from the contraction suffered last April when the commercial hub Shanghai was under stringent COVID lockdown. Meanwhile, China's retail sales jumped 18.4% (missing forecasts for a 21% increase). But it was still much faster retail growth, comapred to the 10.6% increase in March. Fixed asset investment expanded 4.7% in the first four months of 2023 (from the same period a year earlier). Again, it missed analysts' expectations for a 5.5% rise.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Aussie dollar slips on weaker-than-expected China data

children.content: The Australian dollar has slipped 0.3% to 66.8 US cents.
The local currency fell after the latest economic data from key trading partner China fell short of analysts' forecasts, adding to evidence of a sputtering COVID recovery.
China's industrial output grew 5.6% in April (from a year earlier), according to official data. This missed expectations by a large margin, as economists were expecting a 10.9% increase.

But it was still the quicket growth since September 2022, largely due to the recoil effect from the contraction suffered last April when the commercial hub Shanghai was under stringent COVID lockdown.
Meanwhile, China's retail sales jumped 18.4% (missing forecasts for a 21% increase).
But it was still much faster retail growth, comapred to the 10.6% increase in March.
Fixed asset investment expanded 4.7% in the first four months of 2023 (from the same period a year earlier).
Again, it missed analysts' expectations for a 5.5% rise.

image.altText: A collection of Chiang Kai-shek statues lumped together in a park

items.synopsis: Taiwan is littered with monuments to one of its most divisive leaders. However, as efforts to remove them stall, some activists to are taking matters into their own hands.

title.children: Statues of a 'ruthless' dictator are all over Taiwan. His critics keep dumping them in this park
